reviewText: It was almost impossible to believe its history when we watched this film.  Mid- to late-1940s France, when Europe was still reeling from World War II, and the Roman Catholic Church had entered a new place in international criticism - all of these factors made this movie really significant.  The performances, too, were impeccable and the directing was refined.  Not a movie for everyone, but an outstanding film nonetheless.

reviewText: I had a very fond memory of a 35mm print. Despite a very good DVD restoration, the film has aged because of the players, many of them from the Comédie Franaise (or former members). This is specially true for the weak feminine parts, with uninteresting characters.We have the compulsory scene with Richelieu REALLY bothering two innocent kittens.The aristocratic and monarchy riffraff were responsible for the general destitution, more than poverty, also for the constant wars.Here Vincent can push them to give some money and some of their time, always asking for more, which is the main dramatic ploy of the story.It is impossible to show true poverty, so the film is not successful in that way.The strength of the film is the character of St Vincent de Paul, from a poor family, shown at the beginning, having flown his rich Parisian protectors to become a poor parish priest (with suspected plague in the vilage). We are shown the poverty through his reactions and actions.So it is definitely not a Sulpician film or edifying one. Pierre Fresnay is outstanding, with a meridional accent (not the Pagnol one), making us feel his Christian suffering. In the fifties, he would have too many morally noble characters parts.The photography by our great HENRI DECAE is outstanding too.JEAN ANOUILH is again fashinoable in France, due to a reissue of his theatre in the "prestigious' PLEIADE collection.Like many playwrights, he went from great plays to self important ones, not wanting to wake up the brains of the FIGARO readers.We hear many statements which are not artificial, serve the Vincent character and are not theatrical.The film only won an honorary Oscar but was a huge success in France, due to the popularity of Fresnay and canvassing by the Catholic Church.The director MAURICE CLCHE was known for his laments about himself and his family, when something went wrong during the shooting, a nicer tactic than Preminger's.The film escapes the two dark holes of French cinema: the quality film and the prestige film.Unfortunately, we have gone back to the quality film with formerly great directors such as TAVERNIER and ALAIN CORNEAU.We have now outstanding actors again. We had four giants then: Gabin, Raimu, Fresnay and Michel Simon

reviewText: Here's a delightful film: MONSIEUR VINCENT, from France in 1947.  We've all seen those second hand stores and drop-off bins scattered throughout our cities.  Well Here's the man who began it all.  MONSIEUR VINCENT is in reality Saint Vincent de Paul, an heroic priest who devoted himself to the poor when France was enduring, without much patience,  The Black Plague.  Pierre Fresnay plays MONSIEUR VINCENT with stunning simplicity.  He is a product of la Comedie Francaise, and acts with a sincerity that Hollywood had yet to discover.In truth, MONSIEUR VINCENT was able to gather around him wealthy aristocrats, a couple of "royals," enlighten them about the plight of the poor, and get them energized to work with him.  It's interesting to remember that MONSIEUR VINCENT, (St. Vincent de Paul), also founded the Sisters of Charity, those nuns that Hollywood delighted to show because of their enormous white wingspread head gear.  (Our misogynistic priesthood dubbed them "God's Geese").MONSIEUR VINCENT is exquisitely photographed; the story telling is linear and easy to follow.  There's not a single "miracle scene" in MONSIEUR VINCENT, yet you cannot mistake, because of the direction and Fresnay's performance, that here indeed is a man endowed with "the odour of sanctity."Of course MONSIEUR VINCENT is in French with English subtitles, but don't panic, the acting of the entire ensemble is so well crafted that you don't really need the subtitles.Amazon has it on DVD, reasonably priced.  Don't overlook it.Peace,P the G

reviewText: This is, of course, a European film..not Hollywood.  Poverty is represented more realistically than in other films...and it touches the heart.  One realizes the hardships of those less fortunate, but more than that, the Charity and patience of the great St. Vincent.  The Saint is portrayed so well that one almost forgets that its a film at all...and its worth meditating on when he refers to the poor as "his masters".  Most of us have it wrong...we think ourselves to be something for the alms we give...and in this film, the Saint corrects our misguided notions.The one odd thing is that there is a monstrous time gap between when St. Vincent is trying in vain to convince his "Daughters" to care for abandoned illegitimate children..and suddenly all is resolved, and all is going well..?I would highly recommend this work.  Be prepared tobe changed by it.
Title: N/A

reviewText: An excellent movie, made in 1948 but on a timeless theme.  Vincent de Paul is an important figure in French history, not just in Church history, but surely most Americans have never heard of him.  His influence in the world grew after his time through the religious orders that he helped to found, especially the Daughters of Charity, whose presence in the world I continue to find evidence of in secular history.  For example, they served during the American Civil War, and at least one valuable memoir would not have been written without them, because they saved the life of the author.

reviewText: MONSIEUR VINCENT (1947) Directed by Maurice Cloche.Starring Pierre Fresnay(as Vincent de Paul), Germaine Dermoz(as Queen Anne) and Aime Clariond as Cardinal Richelieu.This French film..the biography of St Vincent de Paul who living in the 1600s during the reign of King Louis the 13th---dedicated his life to helping the poor makes for a highly pleasing and educational film.Since de Paul lived during the time of D' Artagnon and De Bergerac and the film's touching upon the era are invariably swashbucklers or high romances, this picture gives the viewer a rare and interesting view into another aspect of French culture during the era without sword fights and palace intrigue. And seeing both Richelieu and Queen Anne--major characters in the aforementioned adventure tales--interact with de Paul--the Queen actually making a reference to the Three Musketeers--creates a delightful mise en scene and expansion of historical perception.As for the film itself, it dramatizes the period extremely well and handles de Paul's unyielding character with insight and verve. Fresnay is very good in what is perhaps the most difficult part for an actor--playing a Saint. I tended to think that the film ran a bit long...nearly two hours when perhaps 90 minutes would have serviced. And the film may annoy the politically correct whom--besides their bigotry towards Christianity in general and Catholicism in specific--will probably become outraged when de Paul begins a campaign to save illegitimate infants abandoned in the dark French nights to die in the face of opposition from the heretofore charitable nobility who believe that such children are better off receiving these late term abortions.........Solid interesting film. Worth seeing.I have often thought that the French ARE capable of making good films and may, in fact, do but only send us their pretentious rubbish just to be contrary.  This film gives truth to that thought.............
summary: While D'Artagnon was buckling his swash, there was............
